tweets.text: Everyone's hacking their $20 Claude subscription to run agents. I just pay for the API. My agents have run 24/7 for months, zero bans, zero drama. Sometimes the 'expensive' route is the cheap one.

Figma just shipped an MCP that turns Claude Code UI into editable Figma frames. I spent 15 years as an art director before I started building AI systems. This is the first tool that actually sits at the intersection of both.
Personal branding didn't ruin LinkedIn. Lazy AI slop did. There's a difference between documenting real results and outsourcing your voice to GPT. 110K followers in 12 months, I wrote every word.
tweets.error:
429 Too Many Requests
Too Many Requests

tweets.text: I run 7 AI agents from one orchestrator. They research trends, write tweets, build carousels, and publish my content, every day. Total daily cost: less than a coffee. Built it once. It runs forever.
tweets.error:
429 Too Many Requests
Too Many Requests

tweets.text: OpenClaw's creator got hired by OpenAI. Everyone's debating the implications. I woke up to 5 Skool posts written, a LinkedIn post queued, and trend research done, all before 7am. Debates are interesting. Systems are better.
Everyone's building n8n workflows to replace their $1,500/mo VA. I built mine to replace myself. Research, writing, posting, image gen, publishing, all automated. The VA was never the bottleneck.

Giving away Claude API access to get customers is thinking too small. Give away the OUTPUT of your AI system. People don't want access to a tool. They want the result. That's the only offer worth making.
110K followers. $27K/month. I document everything publicly while I build toward $1M. No gatekeeping. You get what I get, as I get it. That's the whole thing.
